item.title: By: ThatRickGuy
item.dc:creator: ThatRickGuy
item.content:encoded:
Most of our security is run through Active Directory. So even if someone were to compromise the database, they would still have to know which AD group to inject (if even there is an AD group with the security that they want). And out DBA is pretty rock solid on keeping things locked down.

But like all in-house dev teams we have to weigh the costs, risks, and the benefits. Sure, we could likely make the system more secured. But at this point, any intrusion would have to be made from someone acting inside the network on the domain with an auditable connection to the database.

No software solution is uncrackable. It is always just a matter of time and desire to break through any digital lock. Similar to a fire door or a secured safe, they are rated in the amount of time that the can resist assault. So we develop our software with the goal of being able to dissuade most low-medium risks. Anything more than that and our development costs rise with out the company “selling more cheese powder” as my boss likes to say.

So find a happy medium. In our case, the security we have has held up against all would be assaults so far, and we have a tried and true recovery plan for the servers and data. While the centralized maintenance has allowed us to detect and correct configuration errors and even alter production functionality with out deployments.

-Rick

item.title: By: FFGuitar
item.dc:creator: FFGuitar
item.description: I'm starting to get a little leery of the idea of storing all config data in a database (referencing the EP). a good hacker only needs to hack one source for the entire solution and then fwap! offline you go. while it's an interesting and useful idea to create a repository of metadeta, do you really want to store items like connection strings and (dare I say) user info (see DotNetNuke et al)? I fear it's potential lethality to some gimboid coder that doesn't know how to configure database security properly on a production system. fwap! OLUG!
